name: Friction Investigation
subject: Science
curriculum_reference: KS2 Science: Forces — notice that some forces need contact between two objects, but magnetic forces can act at a distance
Y5 Forces: identify the effects of air resistance, water resistance and friction, that act between moving surfaces
pedagogical_rationale: Fair testing is the cornerstone enquiry type for KS2, and friction provides a concrete, measurable context that pupils can investigate with everyday materials. Varying surface type while measuring distance travelled builds understanding of variables, fair testing, and the concept of friction as a contact force that opposes motion.
common_pitfalls: Pupils confuse friction with gravity or air resistance — clarify friction requires contact between two surfaces
Inconsistent release of the car on the ramp leads to unreliable data — model a consistent release technique
Pupils may think smooth surfaces have 'no friction' rather than 'less friction'
cross_curricular_hooks: [Maths] Measuring in centimetres, recording in tables, drawing bar charts
[English] Writing a scientific conclusion using causal connectives (because, therefore, as a result)
[DT] Exploring friction in mechanisms and moving parts
equipment: surface samples (carpet, wood, sandpaper, tile, fabric)
safety_notes: Low risk. Ensure ramp is stable and surfaces are secured flat. Keep the floor area clear to prevent tripping over ramp equipment.
expected_outcome: Rougher surfaces produce more friction, so the car travels a shorter distance. Smooth surfaces produce less friction.
misconceptions: Friction only happens when things are moving — in fact, static friction acts on stationary objects too
Smooth surfaces have no friction — all surfaces have some friction, smooth surfaces just have less
Friction is always unhelpful — friction is essential for walking, gripping, and braking

variables.independent: surface type (carpet, wood, sandpaper, tile, fabric)

name: Plant Growth Enquiry
subject: Science
curriculum_reference: KS2 Science: Living things and their habitats — explore the requirements of plants for life and growth
Y3 Plants: investigate the way in which water is transported within plants; explore the requirements of plants for life and growth
pedagogical_rationale: Fair testing plant growth over several weeks develops pupils' ability to plan long-running investigations, take repeat measurements, and draw conclusions from real-world data that includes natural variation. The light variable is accessible and produces dramatic, visible results that motivate scientific explanation.
common_pitfalls: Pupils water plants inconsistently across conditions, undermining the fair test — establish a watering rota
Pupils expect results within days rather than weeks — set expectations and use a measurement schedule
Confusing the plant growing tall in the dark (etiolation) with healthy growth — discuss what 'healthy growth' means
cross_curricular_hooks: [Maths] Measuring height in centimetres, plotting line graphs to show change over time
[English] Writing up a method using imperative verbs and time connectives
[Geography] Discussing how climate and light availability affect plant growth globally
safety_notes: Wash hands after handling soil. Avoid allergenic plants — check for allergies before choosing plant species. No consumption of experimental plants.
expected_outcome: Plants in full sunlight grow tallest. Plants in the dark grow tall and spindly (etiolated) but pale. Plants need light for healthy growth.
misconceptions: Plants get their food from the soil — plants make their own food through photosynthesis; they absorb water and minerals from soil
Plants only need water and sunlight to grow — plants also need carbon dioxide and minerals
A tall plant is always a healthy plant — etiolated plants in the dark grow tall but are weak and pale

variables.independent: amount of light (dark cupboard, partial shade, full sunlight)

name: Rocks and Fossils
subject: Science
curriculum_reference: Y3 Rocks: compare and group together different kinds of rocks on the basis of their appearance and simple physical properties
Y3 Rocks: describe in simple terms how fossils are formed when things that have lived are trapped within rock
Y3 Rocks: recognise that soils are made from rocks and organic matter
pedagogical_rationale: Identifying and classifying is an essential science enquiry type that develops pupils' observational skills and ability to use evidence to sort and group. Rocks provide a tangible, hands-on context where pupils can handle real specimens, test properties, and connect classroom science to the real landscape around them.
common_pitfalls: Pupils may assume all shiny rocks are the same type — encourage testing multiple properties before grouping
Fossil formation is often oversimplified to 'a dead animal turns into rock' — model the sedimentation and mineralisation process step by step
Pupils confuse 'soil' with 'dirt' and do not realise soil contains both rock fragments and decayed organic material
cross_curricular_hooks: [Geography] Rock types in the local landscape and how geology shapes landforms
[English] Non-chronological report writing about rock types or fossil formation
[History] How fossils changed scientific understanding of Earth's history
equipment: rock samples (granite, chalk, sandstone, slate, marble)
safety_notes: Supervise scratch tests — tools can be sharp. Vinegar is a mild acid — avoid contact with eyes. Wash hands after handling rocks and soil samples.
expected_outcome: Pupils classify rocks by hardness, appearance, and reaction to acid. They understand that fossils form in sedimentary rock and that soil contains rock fragments plus organic material.
misconceptions: All rocks are the same — rocks differ in hardness, grain size, permeability, and formation process
Fossils are dinosaur bones — fossils can be from any organism and include shells, plants, and trace fossils like footprints
Rocks do not change — rocks are slowly broken down by weathering and erosion and can be reformed over geological time

name: Sound Investigation
subject: Science
curriculum_reference: Y4 Sound: identify how sounds are made, associating some of them with something vibrating
Y4 Sound: find patterns between the pitch of a sound and features of the object that produced it
Y4 Sound: find patterns between the volume of a sound and the strength of the vibrations that produced it
Y4 Sound: recognise that sounds get fainter as the distance from the sound source increases
pedagogical_rationale: Pattern seeking develops pupils' ability to identify relationships in data without controlling all variables — an essential skill for real-world science. Sound provides an engaging, multi-sensory context where pupils can see, feel, and hear the evidence for vibrations, making abstract concepts about waves tangible.
common_pitfalls: Pupils confuse pitch and volume — use clear examples to distinguish (e.g. whispering a high note vs shouting a low note)
Pupils think sound only travels through air — demonstrate sound travelling through solids using string telephones or pressing an ear to a desk
Difficulty seeing that 'vibration' is the cause of all sound — use rice on a drum skin and tuning forks in water to make vibrations visible
cross_curricular_hooks: [Music] Pitch and dynamics in musical instruments — how instruments produce different notes
[Maths] Measuring and ordering, recognising patterns in data
[DT] Designing and building a simple musical instrument
sensitive_content_notes: Be aware of pupils with hearing impairments — adapt activities to include visual and tactile ways to experience vibration
safety_notes: Keep volume levels reasonable to protect hearing. Tuning forks can be sharp at the prongs — demonstrate correct use before pupils handle them. Do not strike tuning forks on hard surfaces as they may chip.
expected_outcome: Sounds are caused by vibrations. Higher pitch = faster vibrations (shorter/tighter object). Louder sound = bigger vibrations. Sound travels through solids, liquids, and gases.
misconceptions: Sound can travel through space (a vacuum) — sound needs a medium (solid, liquid, or gas) to travel through
Louder sounds travel faster than quieter sounds — volume does not affect the speed of sound
Only musical instruments make pitched sounds — all sounds have a pitch, even noise

variables.independent: length of vibrating object (ruler overhang, elastic band tension)

name: Electrical Circuits
subject: Science
curriculum_reference: Y4 Electricity: identify common appliances that run on electricity; construct a simple series electrical circuit
Y6 Electricity: associate the brightness of a lamp or the volume of a buzzer with the number and voltage of cells used in the circuit
Y6 Electricity: use recognised symbols when representing a simple circuit in a diagram
pedagogical_rationale: Electricity provides an ideal context for fair testing because pupils can systematically vary one component (number of batteries or bulbs) and immediately observe the effect on brightness. Building and troubleshooting real circuits develops practical skills alongside conceptual understanding of complete loops and conductors/insulators.
common_pitfalls: Pupils think electricity is 'used up' by the bulb — current flows around a complete circuit and is not consumed
Connecting wires incorrectly and concluding 'it doesn't work' — teach systematic troubleshooting of circuit connections
Confusing voltage (push) with current (flow) — use a water pipe analogy at KS2 level
cross_curricular_hooks: [Maths] Drawing circuit diagrams using standard symbols accurately
[DT] Incorporating a simple circuit into a product (e.g. a torch or alarm)
[English] Writing instructions for building a circuit using imperative verbs
sensitive_content_notes: Emphasise that mains electricity is extremely dangerous — pupils must NEVER experiment with mains sockets or plug sockets
Only use low-voltage cells (1.5V) in classroom activities
safety_notes: Use only low-voltage cells (1.5V). Never connect directly across battery terminals (short circuit risk — wires can get hot). Do not use mains electricity. Ensure pupils understand the difference between safe classroom circuits and dangerous mains electricity.
expected_outcome: More batteries = brighter bulb. More bulbs in series = dimmer each bulb. Metals conduct; plastic, rubber, wood insulate. Circuits need a complete loop.
misconceptions: Electricity is used up by the bulb — current is the same everywhere in a series circuit; energy is transferred, not consumed
A single wire from the battery to the bulb is enough — a complete loop is needed for current to flow
Thicker wires mean more electricity — wire thickness affects resistance, not the amount of electricity from the battery

variables.independent: number of batteries (voltage) or number of bulbs

name: States of Matter and the Water Cycle
subject: Science
curriculum_reference: Y4 States of matter: compare and group materials together, according to whether they are solids, liquids or gases
Y4 States of matter: observe that some materials change state when they are heated or cooled
Y4 States of matter: identify the part played by evaporation and condensation in the water cycle
pedagogical_rationale: Observation over time is the ideal enquiry type for evaporation because the process is too slow for a single lesson but produces clear, measurable results over a week. Combining hands-on state change demonstrations with the longer evaporation investigation helps pupils connect everyday experiences (puddles drying, windows steaming) to the scientific model of particle behaviour.
common_pitfalls: Pupils think the water 'disappears' during evaporation rather than understanding it becomes water vapour in the air
Confusing melting and dissolving — melting is a change of state caused by heating, dissolving is a substance mixing into a liquid
Difficulty classifying some materials (e.g. sand, jelly) — discuss that individual grains of sand are solid even though sand can be poured
cross_curricular_hooks: [Maths] Measuring volume in millilitres, reading thermometers, plotting results
[Geography] The water cycle as a geographical process — linking to rivers and weather
[English] Explanation text writing about the water cycle
safety_notes: Teacher demonstrates boiling water — pupils do not handle hot water or kettles. Thermometers should be non-mercury. Supervise any activity involving hot liquids. Ensure pupils stand back during steam demonstrations.
expected_outcome: Solids have fixed shape, liquids take container shape, gases fill available space. Heating causes melting/evaporation, cooling causes condensation/freezing. The water cycle is a continuous process.
misconceptions: Steam and water vapour are the same thing — steam is visible (tiny water droplets); water vapour is an invisible gas
Melting and dissolving are the same process — melting is a state change caused by heat; dissolving is a substance mixing into a solvent
Water only evaporates when it boils — evaporation happens at any temperature from the surface of a liquid

variables.independent: location of water sample (sunny windowsill, shaded shelf, cupboard)

name: Light and Shadows
subject: Science
curriculum_reference: Y3 Light: recognise that they need light in order to see things and that dark is the absence of light
Y3 Light: recognise that shadows are formed when the light from a light source is blocked by an opaque object
Y6 Light: recognise that light appears to travel in straight lines; use the idea that light travels in straight lines to explain why shadows have the same shape as the objects that cast them
pedagogical_rationale: Fair testing the relationship between distance and shadow size produces a clear, quantitative pattern that pupils can graph and explain using the model of light travelling in straight lines. The investigation bridges practical measurement skills with the abstract idea of ray diagrams, building towards the Y6 requirement to explain how we see objects.
common_pitfalls: Pupils think their eyes send out light to see objects — reinforce that we see because light reflects off objects into our eyes
Difficulty understanding that the shadow is not 'attached' to the object — use a torch and move both object and screen
Assuming coloured filters make coloured shadows — the shadow is where light is blocked, not where colour appears
cross_curricular_hooks: [Maths] Measuring shadow lengths, plotting line graphs, identifying proportional relationships
[Art] Shadow puppetry and silhouette art
[English] Descriptive writing using light and shadow imagery
safety_notes: Do not shine torches directly into eyes. Supervise mirror use — reflected light can dazzle. Darken the room for best results but ensure safe movement.
expected_outcome: Shadows form when opaque objects block light. Shadow size increases as the object moves closer to the light source. Light travels in straight lines. We see objects because light reflects off them into our eyes.
misconceptions: Our eyes send out light beams to see things — we see because light enters our eyes after reflecting off objects
Shadows have colour — shadows are areas where light is blocked and appear dark, not coloured
Light only travels in straight lines from torches, not from the sun — all light travels in straight lines regardless of source

variables.independent: distance between light source and object

name: Human Body: Digestion and Teeth
subject: Science
curriculum_reference: Y4 Animals including humans: describe the simple functions of the basic parts of the digestive system in humans
Y4 Animals including humans: identify the different types of teeth in humans and their simple functions
Y4 Animals including humans: construct and interpret a variety of food chains, identifying producers, predators and prey
pedagogical_rationale: Research enquiry is the appropriate approach here because the digestive system cannot be directly investigated through experiment in a primary classroom. Combining research with physical models (egg shell tooth decay experiment, food chain card sorting) ensures pupils engage actively with the content rather than passively reading, building both knowledge and scientific communication skills.
common_pitfalls: Pupils think digestion only happens in the stomach — the process starts in the mouth and continues through the intestines
Confusing food chains and food webs — start with simple chains before introducing the complexity of webs
Pupils may think arrows in food chains show 'who eats who' rather than 'energy is transferred to' — clarify arrow direction
cross_curricular_hooks: [English] Non-chronological report writing about the digestive system
[Maths] Interpreting data about tooth decay from the egg shell experiment
[PSHE] Healthy eating and dental hygiene
sensitive_content_notes: Be sensitive to pupils with dietary restrictions or eating difficulties when discussing food and digestion
Avoid framing food as 'good' or 'bad' — focus on the scientific process of digestion
safety_notes: Egg shell experiment uses cola — no drinking of experimental liquids. Hand washing after handling food items and models. If using mirrors for tooth observation, ensure they are unbreakable.
expected_outcome: Pupils can describe the journey of food through the digestive system, name and describe functions of different tooth types, and construct food chains with producers, predators and prey.
misconceptions: The stomach is the only organ involved in digestion — digestion is a whole-body process involving mouth, oesophagus, stomach, small intestine, and large intestine
Food chain arrows point from the predator to the prey — arrows show the direction of energy transfer, from prey to predator
Humans only have one type of teeth — humans have incisors, canines, and molars, each with different functions

name: Evolution and Adaptation
subject: Science
curriculum_reference: Y6 Evolution and inheritance: recognise that living things have changed over time and that fossils provide information about living things that inhabited the Earth millions of years ago
Y6 Evolution and inheritance: identify how animals and plants are adapted to suit their environment in different ways and that adaptation may lead to evolution
pedagogical_rationale: Research enquiry combined with hands-on modelling (the beak adaptation simulation) helps pupils understand natural selection through concrete experience rather than abstract explanation. The bird beak activity transforms a complex concept into a physical investigation where pupils can see variation, competition, and differential survival in action.
common_pitfalls: Pupils think individual organisms evolve during their lifetime — evolution happens across populations over many generations
Confusing adaptation (a trait that helps survival) with acclimatisation (a short-term response) — use clear examples
Pupils may think evolution is a deliberate choice by organisms ('the giraffe stretched its neck') — emphasise random variation and natural selection
cross_curricular_hooks: [History] How Darwin's theory changed scientific and religious thinking
[Geography] How different environments around the world have shaped different adaptations
[English] Writing a biography of a significant scientist (Darwin, Wallace, Mary Anning)
sensitive_content_notes: Evolution can conflict with some religious beliefs — present it as the scientific explanation supported by evidence, while being respectful of pupils' faith backgrounds
Focus on evidence and the scientific process rather than making value judgements about beliefs
safety_notes: No specific physical hazards. Handle fossil samples with care as they can be fragile and valuable. Ensure sensitivity around evolution and creation discussions — follow school RE policy.
expected_outcome: Fossils show how organisms have changed over time. Offspring vary from parents. Organisms are adapted to their environments. Over time, natural selection means better-adapted organisms survive and reproduce.
misconceptions: Evolution means an animal chose to change — evolution is driven by random variation and natural selection, not by choice or intention
Humans evolved from modern monkeys — humans and modern apes share a common ancestor, but neither evolved from the other
Fossils are just old bones — fossils can include shells, teeth, footprints, and even preserved plant material in sedimentary rock

name: Separating Mixtures
subject: Science
curriculum_reference: Y5 Properties and changes of materials: know that some materials will dissolve in liquid to form a solution, and describe how to recover a substance from a solution
Y5 Properties and changes of materials: use knowledge of solids, liquids and gases to decide how mixtures might be separated

Y5 Properties and changes of materials: demonstrate that dissolving, mixing and changes of state are reversible changes; explain that some changes result in the formation of new materials, and that this kind of change is not usually reversible
pedagogical_rationale: Fair testing separation methods gives pupils authentic problem-solving experience — they must choose the right technique for each mixture based on the properties of its components. This builds the critical KS2 skill of using scientific knowledge to make predictions and plan investigations, while the reversible/irreversible distinction develops understanding of chemical change.
common_pitfalls: Pupils confuse dissolving and melting — dissolving involves a solute and solvent at the same temperature; melting involves a state change caused by heat
Pupils think dissolved substances have 'disappeared' — demonstrate recovery by evaporation to prove the substance is still there
Difficulty distinguishing reversible from irreversible changes — use concrete paired examples (ice melting vs egg cooking)
cross_curricular_hooks: [Maths] Measuring volumes accurately, recording data in tables
[DT] Choosing materials with appropriate properties for a purpose
[Geography] Water purification and its importance in different parts of the world
safety_notes: Wear safety goggles during evaporation activities. Teacher supervises all heating. Do not taste solutions or mixtures. Iron filings can irritate eyes — handle carefully and keep magnets away from electronic devices.
expected_outcome: Different mixtures require different separation methods based on particle size and solubility. Dissolving and filtering are reversible. Burning and cooking are irreversible.
misconceptions: Dissolving and melting are the same thing — dissolving involves a solute mixing into a solvent; melting is a state change caused by heating
When something dissolves it disappears — the substance is still present in solution and can be recovered by evaporation
All changes can be undone if you try hard enough — some changes (burning, cooking) form new substances and are irreversible
